## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**AI Assistant:**
Hey there! I'm here to assist you in understanding Verus. What's on your mind today?

**User:**
I'm interested in learning more about the currencies launched on the Verus network. What are some of the features and capabilities of these currencies?

**AI Assistant:**
Currencies launched on the Verus network can be designed to accept a range of other currencies, and can have fractional reserve capabilities. Additionally, the Verus import/export protocol allows for easy and provable integration with other blockchains, such as ETH and ERC20 tokens. Does that make sense?

**User:**
That sounds interesting. What is the significance of the Verus import/export protocol?

**AI Assistant:**
The Verus import/export protocol is designed to make integration with other blockchains easy and provable. This enables automatic send/receive of any Verus network token between Verus and other blockchains, such as ETH and ERC20 tokens. This feature opens up a lot of possibilities for interoperability between different blockchain ecosystems.

**User:**
I've heard about the `sendcurrency` API. How can I use it to send and convert funds on the Verus network?

**AI Assistant:**
The `sendcurrency` API can be used to send and convert funds on the Verus network. You can send funds from a single address to a single recipient, send funds from all wallet funds to multiple recipients, convert funds to another currency, and even preconvert funds to a new currency before it is active. It's a powerful tool that gives you a lot of flexibility when working with currencies on the Verus network.

**User:**
That sounds really useful. I'm a bit unclear on the difference between converting and preconverting funds using the `sendcurrency` API. Can you explain?

**AI Assistant:**
Converting funds using the `sendcurrency` API involves converting funds from one currency to another that is already active on the network. Preconverting funds, on the other hand, involves converting funds to a new currency that is not yet active on the network, with the option to refund the original funds if the conversion is not successful. So, preconverting is a way to prepare for a new currency launch, while converting is a way to switch between existing currencies.

**User:**
I've been playing around with the testnet and I was wondering, what happens to testnet coins and currencies when VRSCTEST is reset?

**AI Assistant:**
All testnet coins and currencies have no value and will disappear whenever VRSCTEST is reset. So, anything you do on the testnet is just for testing and won't have any real-world consequences. This is a great way to try out new ideas and experiment with the Verus network without risking any real assets.
AI Assistant
N/A
What are some of the features and capabilities of currencies launched on the Verus network?

Currencies launched on the Verus network can be designed to accept a range of other currencies, and can have fractional reserve capabilities. Additionally, the Verus import/export protocol allows for easy and provable integration with other blockchains, such as ETH and ERC20 tokens.

Currencies can be launched to accept a range of other currencies and with or without fractional reserve capabilities. Verus import/export protocol was designed to make integration with other block chains provable and easy, and there are already external bridges in progress that expect to enable automatic send/receive of any Verus network token between Verus and ETH/ERC20 tokens, where currencies can be sent between Verus and ETH, expressed as Verus currencies on the Verus network, and exposed automatically on ETH as an ERC20 token.# Preparing for Multi-chain, Dynamic Merge Mining While this 0.7.1 testnet enables on-chain token currency definition, the same advances will soon be available on the Verus merge mining and multi-chain technology which was running on testnet last year. When enabled, this will make it possible for Verus network chains to operate fully independently, yet be dynamically merge mineable along with Verus and up to 20 other Verus network blockchains on a single hash, earning rewards and powering all chains simultaneously. All network blockchains will provide the same fractional currency capabilities, both for on-chain tokens as well as native zk-SNARK supporting currencies as well.## Sending and Converting Currency **Warning: All testnet coins/currencies have no value and will disappear whenever VRSCTEST is reset**The `sendcurrency` API can be used to send and convert funds. **Sending VRSCTEST from a single address (bob@) to a single recipient (alice@):** ``` verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "bob@" '[{"currency":"vrsctest","address":"alice@","amount":10}]' ``` **Sending VRSCTEST from all wallet funds to two recipients (alice@ and bob@):** ``` verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "*" '[{"currency":"vrsctest","address":"alice@","amount":10},{"currency":"VRSCTEST","address":"bob@","amount":10}]' ``` **Converting VRSCTEST to another currency, TESTCOIN:** ``` verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "*" '[{"address":"bob@","amount":10, "convertto":"TESTCOIN"}]' ``` **Preconverting to new currency, NEWCOIN, before it is active:** ``` verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "*" '[{"address":"alice@","amount":10, "convertto":"NEWCOIN", "preconvert":true, "refundto":"alice@"}]' ```## Defining a Currency
